IlIPWRECk.--Captain AI'Ciintock and TIE
surviving crew Of the brg Try-Agrn, (l3 IN mum
ber,) beng indebted nnfler Providence. to Capt. :.
Baldwin, Of the packet ship alexander, OF fhndel
pha for the preservation Of their lives, BEG leave
70 express their gratitude, By publicly arkn Flelg-
ins the Obligations they are under The kind at
tenton which, they received while on board, togcth-
er with the noble and gencrots act in leas lug ms
course, To rescue taem ron the ui~orles Of "a In
gering death, wii be remembered TO tbe last hour Of
their iIvus. They beg, therefore, TO tender 10
Capt baldwin, their hrst wishes for his health and


prosperit yand TO assure INN, that his benevolent
conduct shall not be forgotten. The brig Try sab
sailed from Quebec lth Oct. bound 10 LiverpooI


with cargo OF timber. On the 22d, in lat. As N.


long SO W. were overtaken by a severe gale OF wind


from N. to ". 2}d, at 30 min. a. II. urled all sail
and hove the ship 10, de pmnls constantly going


but not able 10 keep her free. During the day she


abonrod much, an: shipped dead of water. At
8 O'Clock and SO m. r. Nj. on tie 24th shipped d
sea which wapt the decks fore and aft, leaving no
thing standing but the foremost and stump Of the
nmnmast. Iwoot the crew, James Robinson, and
Duncan Wler, were swept over and drowned. AT
ter clearing the wreck, we found the ship half full


OF water, and totally unmanageablc, having lost her
ru'lder. We then prepared some provisions for the
purpose Of securing ourselves on the ioretop, but
had sooner placed them on deck than they were
swept oil. We were then obliged to repair to the
A top without food or water, and there remain for
four days. On the morning of the 9TH, being near
| ly exhausted, and the weather more moderate. we
went on deck in search of provisions. Two casks
OF water had been slowed in the steerage, and one


with difficulty was brought on deck which had been
slowed, and quantity Of salt water admitted we
however secured it TO the windass, and with IG


pounds of beef repaired again 10 the top, where we
!, remained days during which time ten vessels pas


scd us in particular within musket shot, but tc


our surprise, she altered her course and stood from


us. Our beefnow being exhausted, and having no
thing left but this bracksh water, our sufferincs be
: come very great. Some Of the crew then sugges
: ted that lots should be cast for one to die for th


sustenance of the others, but two not agreeing, WI
/ were fortunately preserved on the goth November
by the ship Alexander, capt. Baldwin, who sent tw


boats 10 our assistance. AT this moment our feeling
Erom he Pclasulrnlio Ga.ette.

We have seen a letter from distinguished mem
Der of Congress, and one too, whose opportunities
of obtaining information enttle his opinions to the
highest respect, which speaks in the most confident
terms of Mr. Adams re eelcction We have been
permitted to make the following exract


II can only say, AM CONFIDENT WE
SHALL PREVAIL From this time the tide win
set against the ruthless Opposition. Their very
foundation the charge of corruption,) is swept
lrou under them by the discussions of the past sea-
son. Nothing has sustained them from sinking for
long time, but factitinns results of elections.
supported by the steady end txt sentiments of the
people. We have now done with these, and must
recur again toprinciples whenwe must prevail.

with the foregoing resolutions.

MIR. Miller presented the petition.--0f John |
Blake, Revolutionary officer. who entered the ser
vice in April l775; who was in the battles Of Long
Island. Iarlaem Heights East cheser W bite Plains
Trenton Saratoga, Saltwater, Stoney Point, besides
ia score Of skiimshes.
The following is an extract from the petition:


"When in the Jerseys, captured several small
detaehments Of refugees, which 50 irrtated their
commander, Col. Delanca, that he offered a reward
of sixty guneas to any person who might bring mel
to him, dead or alive. General Washington, then
at Crumpond. in the State of New York wrote me
ii letter TO repair to his quarters. When arrived.
he SAYS, Friend Blake, have a pleasant tour Of
duty for you, which,. to take a detachment of men,
and make Col. Deanca and his guard prisoners


have heard he has offered bounty for you !;
therefore give you this opportunity to rctaIae.'
i Accordingly, the following night. repaired to lis
quarters but before arrived took two Of his men
who gave me the comdersiga, by which means |
was enabled to take the scntncls without alarming
the guard found the door boltcd and went to the
window, where | saw several officers playing at
cards, one Of whom inquired Uhm 1caS trumps? |
Immediately answered, Biack Jack. Of MeNh hfg.
i. imcat? at the same time ordering the window bro
ken. The guard OI 36 men and officers were made
prisoners, but the T. lionel was absent and escaped


Il have at last attained to my 14tb year, without
receiving the compen> ,on due for my services. and
have lately had the misfortune OF having one OF my
arms broken yet am under the necessity, even de-
bilitated and disabled am, of tutoring to support
life But soon will the vital spark expire, and free
my country from my pressing opportunities. Shall
! Congress be rcproached with partialityP Why
r them do some who served only nine months receive
their pensions as many years. whilst others. because
they have, by persevering industry obtained scan
ty pltance are remanded from their country's gen
erosity9 sincerely hope that, while she so liberal
y rewards meritorious foreigners, who entered The
service at the eleventh hour She will not be unmind
Iul of the ireeborn sons of America, who bore the
heat and burthen of the day. My countrymen,
reckon upon your justice and generosity.
\ The petition was referred to the Committee oil
Pensions.

The following description Of the President Is co
pied from address adopted at a late public lace
ting iii Louisville. Every honest man Will ackn0w-
ledge the correctness OF the likeness drawn, and il
is difficult for us TO see with what prctcxt certain
partlsaus can arm themselves for thrusting such
man out of his office The address says the Pres
ident Of the U. States is.--


4 man who from his youth, has been trained Up
IN the politics the country. and whose name found
every where c0.lSpicuouSiy connected with its histo
ry.


A man who in his youth was distinguished Cor his
correct habits his assdulty in acquiring useful know
ledge. whose character for integrity and patriotism
has never been questioned by the bitterness of par
ty spirit


A man of the first order of intellect of long ex.
periencc calm and deliberate in his measures, and
iirm III his purpose


A man who through his whole life, public and pri
vate, in all its particulars, will bear the test o
human scrutiny, OF talents and of time''-a private
life honorable TO country


A man who was pronounced, more than thirt,
years ago, by our political father the sainted Wash
inston, of our most valuable public characters


A man who enjoyed the confidence, and partci
pated in the administrations Of Washington, JeEer
son, Madison and Monroe.


Altman pronounced by Monroe entitled to conf
iencc from his long tservices, his acknowledge
;itiities, and 0nluestioned integrity.
G. w. Richards, Sec'ry.

full articles.headline: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES, Dec. ls.
full articles.article:
MIR. Miller presented the petition.--0f John |
Blake, Revolutionary officer. who entered the ser
vice in April l775; who was in the battles Of Long
Island. Iarlaem Heights East cheser W bite Plains
Trenton Saratoga, Saltwater, Stoney Point, besides
ia score Of skiimshes.
The following is an extract from the petition:


"When in the Jerseys, captured several small
detaehments Of refugees, which 50 irrtated their
commander, Col. Delanca, that he offered a reward
of sixty guneas to any person who might bring mel
to him, dead or alive. General Washington, then
at Crumpond. in the State of New York wrote me
ii letter TO repair to his quarters. When arrived.
he SAYS, Friend Blake, have a pleasant tour Of
duty for you, which,. to take a detachment of men,
and make Col. Deanca and his guard prisoners


have heard he has offered bounty for you !;
therefore give you this opportunity to rctaIae.'
i Accordingly, the following night. repaired to lis
quarters but before arrived took two Of his men
who gave me the comdersiga, by which means |
was enabled to take the scntncls without alarming
the guard found the door boltcd and went to the
window, where | saw several officers playing at
cards, one Of whom inquired Uhm 1caS trumps? |
Immediately answered, Biack Jack. Of MeNh hfg.
i. imcat? at the same time ordering the window bro
ken. The guard OI 36 men and officers were made
prisoners, but the T. lionel was absent and escaped


Il have at last attained to my 14tb year, without
receiving the compen> ,on due for my services. and
have lately had the misfortune OF having one OF my
arms broken yet am under the necessity, even de-
bilitated and disabled am, of tutoring to support
life But soon will the vital spark expire, and free
my country from my pressing opportunities. Shall
! Congress be rcproached with partialityP Why
r them do some who served only nine months receive
their pensions as many years. whilst others. because
they have, by persevering industry obtained scan
ty pltance are remanded from their country's gen
erosity9 sincerely hope that, while she so liberal
y rewards meritorious foreigners, who entered The
service at the eleventh hour She will not be unmind
Iul of the ireeborn sons of America, who bore the
heat and burthen of the day. My countrymen,
reckon upon your justice and generosity.
\ The petition was referred to the Committee oil
Pensions.

The following description Of the President Is co
pied from address adopted at a late public lace
ting iii Louisville. Every honest man Will ackn0w-
ledge the correctness OF the likeness drawn, and il
is difficult for us TO see with what prctcxt certain
partlsaus can arm themselves for thrusting such
man out of his office The address says the Pres
ident Of the U. States is.--


4 man who from his youth, has been trained Up
IN the politics the country. and whose name found
every where c0.lSpicuouSiy connected with its histo
ry.


A man who in his youth was distinguished Cor his
correct habits his assdulty in acquiring useful know
ledge. whose character for integrity and patriotism
has never been questioned by the bitterness of par
ty spirit


A man of the first order of intellect of long ex.
periencc calm and deliberate in his measures, and
iirm III his purpose


A man who through his whole life, public and pri
vate, in all its particulars, will bear the test o
human scrutiny, OF talents and of time''-a private
life honorable TO country


A man who was pronounced, more than thirt,
years ago, by our political father the sainted Wash
inston, of our most valuable public characters


A man who enjoyed the confidence, and partci
pated in the administrations Of Washington, JeEer
son, Madison and Monroe.


Altman pronounced by Monroe entitled to conf
iencc from his long tservices, his acknowledge
;itiities, and 0nluestioned integrity.
